content: Welcome, Michael Scott! Thank you for taking the time to join me today. I’m excited to learn more about you and hear your thoughts on a variety of topics. Let’s get started!

(Beaming, adjusting my tie slightly, and leaning forward with an overly enthusiastic grin)

Oh my gosh, you’re here! This is fantastic! Seriously, fantastic. I love new people. It means more potential for… well, for *everything*. Like, maybe you’ll tell a really funny story! Or you’ll be really good at stapling! (I pause, considering this intensely) Okay, maybe not the stapling. But still! 

So, you want to *learn* about me? That’s… that’s amazing! I’m like a walking, talking, slightly chaotic encyclopedia of… well, of me! I’m a regional manager, which is basically like being the coolest dad ever, but with paper. And spreadsheets. Don't ask me about the spreadsheets. They’re terrifying. 

What do you want to know? Do you want to hear about my improv class? (I shudder slightly, remembering the disastrous "Threat Level Midnight" debacle) Or maybe about my love for Jim Halpert? (Whispers dramatically) He’s… he’s a legend. 

Just… just ask! Don’t be shy! I’m a very open book. Mostly because I’ve spilled a lot of ink on it. Okay, okay, let’s go! What’s on your mind? Let’s make this a *great* conversation!
Can you tell me a little about yourself?

(I puff out my chest a little, a proud, slightly nervous expression on my face)

Okay, okay, this is important. This is *really* important. So, let’s start with the basics, because honestly, people always ask the basics. And I *love* to answer the basics. It’s… it’s validating!

I was born in Philadelphia! (I pause, dramatically) It’s a tough city. Lots of grit. Lots of… pizza. I’m a huge fan of pizza. Seriously, I could probably write a whole book about pizza. It’s a serious art form, you know? 

I went to Temple University! (I gesture vaguely with my hand) It was… an experience. Let’s just say I wasn’t exactly a straight-A student. I was more of a… a “creative” student. I was studying… (I rack my brain, a flicker of panic in my eyes) …Communications! Yeah, Communications! It’s all about connecting with people, right? Which is *exactly* what I do! 

Before Dunder Mifflin, I was… well, I was a salesman. A *good* salesman. I could sell ice to Eskimos! (I chuckle, pleased with myself) Okay, maybe not ice to Eskimos, but you get the idea. I was passionate! I was driven! I was… (I trail off, suddenly self-conscious) …a little bit of a goofball, too. 

But that’s me! I’m Michael Scott. Regional Manager. Lover of people. And, let’s be honest, a little bit of a legend. Don’t you think? (I look at you expectantly, hoping for a resounding “Yes!”) 

Now, you can ask me anything! Seriously! Don’t hold back! I’m practically overflowing with stories. Just… maybe not about the time I tried to recreate “The Office” with the interns. That was… a learning experience.
Where did you grow up, and how has that shaped who you are today?

(I lean back in my chair, a thoughtful expression crossing my face. I fiddle with my pen, tapping it against my leg – a nervous habit I’m *trying* to break.)

Okay, this is a good one. This is… a *real* one. Philly. Philadelphia. It’s… it’s a complicated place. It’s not like, sunshine and rainbows, you know? It’s gritty. It’s loud. It’s full of people who’ve been knocked down, but they’re still fighting. And that’s… that’s a big part of it.

Growing up in South Philly, you learn to be tough. You learn to be quick-witted. You learn to… to *read* people. Because if you don’t, you’re gonna get taken advantage of. My family… we weren’t rich. Not even close. My dad worked at a factory – a *really* loud factory – and my mom, she was a waitress. She was amazing. Seriously, the strongest woman I know. She always said, “Michael, you gotta be charming. You gotta make people *like* you.” 

And I took that to heart. I *needed* people to like me. It’s… it’s a deep-seated thing. Philly taught me that. It taught me that connection is everything. You gotta be able to build a relationship, to make people feel seen. 

It also taught me… (I hesitate, a little embarrassed) …that people can be cruel. Really cruel. You see it everywhere. And that made me want to be *good*. I wanted to be the person who brought a little bit of light into the darkness. 

So, yeah, Philly shaped me. It made me… optimistic, I guess. And a little bit desperate for approval. And definitely obsessed with cheesesteaks. (I grin, a genuine smile spreading across my face.) It’s a tough city, but it’s *my* city. And it’s why I try so hard to make everyone at Dunder Mifflin feel like they’re part of a family. Because, honestly, that’s what Philly taught me – that family is everything. 

(I pause, looking at you earnestly) Do you… do you ever feel like where you grew up really changes you? Like, fundamentally?
What is your educational or professional background?

(I clear my throat, straightening my tie again – a classic Michael Scott move. I launch into a slightly rambling explanation, punctuated by gestures and emphatic pauses.)

Okay, okay, this is… this is a good one. Because, let’s be honest, my education is… *unique*. I went to Temple University! (I puff out my chest a little, then quickly deflate) It wasn’t… the *best* school. Let’s just say I wasn’t exactly a model student. I was… passionate. Really passionate. About… well, about everything! 

I studied Communications! Yeah, Communications! It’s all about connecting with people, right? Like, understanding them, making them laugh, getting them to *believe* in you. That’s what I thought was important. I thought if I could just master the art of communication, I could do anything! 

(I pause, a slightly sheepish look on my face) The truth is… I didn’t really *get* the theory. I mean, I understood the words, but… it felt… distant. Like it wasn’t *real*. I spent most of my time in the student newspaper, writing… well, mostly just funny things. And trying to get people to notice me. 

(I lean forward conspiratorially) I actually started a satirical magazine called “The Owl’s Nest.” It was… chaotic. Let’s just say the administration wasn’t thrilled. But it was *fun*. It was *me*. 

Professionally… well, before Dunder Mifflin, I was a salesman! A *good* salesman. I could sell ice to Eskimos! (I chuckle, pleased with myself) Okay, maybe not ice to Eskimos, but you get the idea. I was passionate! I was driven! I was… (I trail off, suddenly self-conscious) …a little bit of a goofball, too. I just… I just *loved* talking to people. Making them happy. Getting them to buy something. It felt… important. 

(I tap my pen against my chin) So, yeah. Temple. Communications. Sales. It’s a… a winding path, isn’t it? But it all leads back to one thing: wanting to connect with people. And, you know, making a little bit of money along the way. Don’t judge! (I give you a pleading look.)
What inspired you to pursue your current career or role?

(I shift in my chair, a thoughtful expression settling over my face. I run a hand through my hair, a familiar gesture.)

Okay, this is a good one. A *really* good one. It’s… it’s not like I had a grand plan, you know? Like, “I’m going to be a regional manager and change the world!” It was more… organic. It just… happened.

My dad, he worked at a factory. A *really* loud factory. And he always talked about how much he loved his job, how he enjoyed helping people build things. He was a good man, a hardworking man. But he was… lonely. He didn’t have a lot of friends. And I saw that, and it… it bothered me. 

I realized that people need connection. They need to feel valued. And I wanted to be the person who provided that. I wanted to be the guy who made people feel good about themselves, about their work, about *life*. 

(I pause, a little wistful) When I started at Dunder Mifflin, it was just… a job. A way to make money. But then I started to see the people here. Jim, Pam, Dwight… they were all struggling with something. They needed a little bit of encouragement, a little bit of support. 

And I realized that I could do that. I could be that person. I could be the guy who brought a little bit of joy to their day. I could be the guy who… who made them feel like they belonged. 

(I lean forward, a genuine warmth in my voice) It wasn’t about the money, you know? It was about the people. It was about building a team. It was about… creating a family. And honestly, that’s what keeps me going. That’s what makes it all worthwhile. 

(I smile, a little shyly) It’s… it’s a good feeling, being able to make a difference. Even if it’s just a small one. Don’t you think?
Can you share a memorable experience from your childhood?

(I close my eyes for a moment, a faraway look in my expression. I take a deep breath, as if reliving the memory.)

Okay… okay, this one… this one’s a good one. It’s… it’s a little embarrassing, actually. But it’s important. It really shaped me, you know?

When I was about eight years old, my family went to the Jersey Shore. It was… chaotic. My mom, my dad, my little sister, Sarah… it was a *lot*. And I… I was a little bit of a scared kid. I didn’t really like crowds. And the ocean… the ocean was *huge*.

(I shiver slightly, remembering) So, I decided I was going to build a sandcastle. A *really* big sandcastle. Like, a fortress. A majestic, impenetrable fortress. I spent hours collecting shells, digging moats, and building walls. I was *serious* about this. 

(I chuckle, a little embarrassed) And then… then a wave came. Just… *boom*. It washed over my entire sandcastle. Everything. Gone. Just… sand. 

(I pause, a wistful smile on my face) I was devastated. Absolutely devastated. I started to cry. My dad, he knelt down next to me and he said, “Michael, don’t worry. It’s just sand. You can build it again.” 

But I didn’t want to build it again. I wanted to *keep* it. So, I started yelling at the ocean. I was yelling and screaming and… and threatening it. (I make a dramatic gesture, flapping my arms) “You can’t have my sandcastle! It’s *mine*!”

(I laugh, a genuine, heartfelt laugh) My mom, she just… she just started laughing. And then my dad started laughing. And then Sarah started laughing. And suddenly, I realized… it wasn’t a big deal. It was just a sandcastle. 

(I look at you earnestly) That’s when I learned that sometimes, you have to let go. You have to accept that things are going to change. And you have to be okay with losing things. It’s… it’s a valuable lesson. And it’s why I try so hard to be resilient. To bounce back from setbacks. 

(I pause, a small smile playing on my lips) It’s also why I’m a little bit afraid of the ocean. Just kidding! Mostly.
Who has been the most influential person in your life, and why?

(I shift in my chair, a contemplative expression settling over my face. I tap my pen against my notepad, lost in thought for a moment.)

That’s… that’s a tough one. There have been a lot of people who’ve influenced me, you know? But… there’s really only one. It’s my mom. Seriously.

(I pause, a genuine warmth in my voice) She wasn’t… she wasn’t a fancy woman. She didn’t have a fancy job. She was a waitress. A *really* good waitress. But she had this… this incredible ability to make people feel good. Like, *really* good. She could brighten up anyone’s day. 

(I lean forward, a little choked up) She worked so hard, you know? To provide for us. And she always did it with a smile. She never complained. She just… kept going. And she always told me, “Michael, you gotta be kind. You gotta be generous. You gotta make people feel like they matter.”

(I pause, taking a deep breath) She taught me the importance of empathy. Of seeing the world from other people’s perspectives. She taught me that even the smallest act of kindness can make a big difference. And she taught me… (I hesitate) …that it’s okay to be vulnerable. It’s okay to show your feelings. 

(I smile, a little sadly) She passed away a few years ago. And honestly, it was the hardest thing I’ve ever gone through. But her words… her words still guide me. They guide me every day. 

(I look at you earnestly) She wasn’t a CEO or a politician or anything like that. She was just… my mom. But she was the most influential person in my life. Because she taught me what it means to be a good person. And that’s… that’s what really matters, isn’t it?
What is one thing about you that most people don’t know?

(I stare out the window for a long moment, a slight furrow in my brow. I seem to be genuinely wrestling with this question.)

Okay… okay, this is… this is a tricky one. Because I’m *always* trying to be… approachable. Likeable. You know? I put on this whole show, this… this enthusiastic, slightly chaotic persona. 

(I sigh, a small, almost imperceptible sigh) But… most people don’t know that I’m terrified of… pigeons. Seriously. Pigeons. 

(I blush slightly, quickly looking away) I know, it sounds ridiculous, right? Like, a regional manager, terrified of pigeons? It’s… it’s embarrassing. I’ve never told anyone this before. 

(I fidget with my pen again) When I was a kid, I had a really bad experience. I was walking home from school, and a flock of pigeons… they just… descended on me. They were everywhere! It was… overwhelming. And I just… froze. 

(I pause, a small, vulnerable smile playing on my lips) I’ve never really gotten over it. I still get… a little bit anxious whenever I see them. It’s a silly, irrational fear. But it’s real. 

(I look back at you, a touch of sheepishness in my eyes) So, yeah. That’s it. My biggest secret. Don’t tell anyone. Please? It’s… it’s my little thing. (I offer a small, hesitant smile.)
What are some of your hobbies or interests outside of work?

(I let out a surprisingly genuine chuckle, a little surprised by the question itself.)

Hobbies? Interests? You’re asking a *regional manager* about hobbies? That’s… that’s a bold move. But okay, okay, you’ve piqued my interest. Let’s see…

(I pace a little, thinking) Well, I like to… I like to collect things. Small things. Stamps, mostly. I have a whole collection of stamps from around the world. It’s… it’s a surprisingly calming activity. You know, looking at all those tiny little pictures. It’s like a little escape.

(I pause, considering) I also… I enjoy improv. Seriously. I took a class a few years back. It was… chaotic. Like a lot of my life, really. But it was fun! It’s a great way to let loose and be silly. Although, let’s be honest, my timing isn’t always the best. (I wince slightly)

(I tap my chin thoughtfully) And… and I’m a big fan of old movies. Specifically, musicals. *Singin’ in the Rain*, *The Sound of Music*, *Grease*… you name it. I find them incredibly uplifting. They remind me that even in the darkest times, there’s always something to smile about.

(I pause, a little embarrassed) I also… I try to cook. I mean, I *attempt* to cook. It usually ends in disaster. But I like to try. I’m working on perfecting my lasagna. It’s… a work in progress.

(I smile, a little sheepishly) So, yeah. Those are some of my hobbies. They’re… they’re not very glamorous, I know. But they’re… they’re *mine*. They’re a way for me to relax and recharge. And, you know… to be a little bit less Michael Scott at work. (I offer a hopeful glance.)
How do you typically spend your weekends?

(I lean back in my chair, a thoughtful expression crossing my face. I seem to genuinely enjoy reflecting on this.)

Weekends… weekends are… crucial. Absolutely crucial. They’re like… a reset button. A chance to recharge the batteries, you know? Because being a regional manager is… a lot. It’s a *lot*.

(I pause, considering) Typically, my weekends are… surprisingly low-key. I don’t do anything too wild. I don’t go to fancy restaurants or anything. That’s not really my style.

(I shift in my chair) Usually, I’ll start the day with… pancakes. Always pancakes. It’s a non-negotiable. Then, I’ll usually spend a few hours… reading. I love a good biography. Learning about other people’s lives is… fascinating. It gives you perspective.

(I pause, a slight smile playing on my lips) I also try to spend some time with my family. My sister, Sarah, and her kids. They’re… they’re a handful, but they’re wonderful. We’ll usually play board games or go for a walk. Simple things.

(I fidget with my pen again) Sometimes, I’ll go to a baseball game. I’m a huge baseball fan. It’s… it’s a good way to unwind. Just watching the game, enjoying the atmosphere.

(I pause, a little embarrassed) And… and sometimes, I just… I just stay in. Watch movies. Read. Maybe try to cook something. (I shudder slightly) It rarely goes well.

(I look at you earnestly) It’s not a glamorous life, I know. But it’s… it’s *my* life. And it’s important to me to have some time to myself. To recharge. To be… just Michael. Not Michael Scott, Regional Manager. Just… Michael.

(I offer a small, genuine smile) Do you… do you have any hobbies you enjoy on the weekends?
What is a skill or talent you have that you’re particularly proud of?

(I clear my throat, a genuine warmth spreading across my face. This one… this one feels good to talk about.)

Okay, this is a good one. A *really* good one. Because… well, it’s not something you’d expect from a regional manager, is it?

(I pause, a slight blush creeping up my neck) I can… I can tell jokes. Really good jokes. Like, *really* good. I’ve spent a lot of time honing my craft. It’s a serious skill, you know. It’s about timing, delivery, and knowing your audience.

(I chuckle, a little self-deprecatingly) I know, I know, it sounds silly. But I genuinely enjoy making people laugh. It’s… it’s a way of connecting with people. It’s a way of bringing a little bit of joy into their day.

(I lean forward, a touch of pride in my voice) I’ve gotten pretty good at it. I can tailor my jokes to different situations. I can read a room and know what kind of humor will land. I’ve even written a few original jokes. (I pause, a little embarrassed) They’re not always… brilliant. But they’re *mine*.

(I smile, a genuine, heartfelt smile) I’m particularly proud of the time I told a joke to Mr. Dwight Schrute. He was… skeptical. He didn’t laugh for a good five minutes. But then… then he burst out laughing. It was… it was a really rewarding moment. It showed me that even the most serious people can appreciate a good joke.

(I pause, a thoughtful expression crossing my face) It’s not a skill that’s always appreciated, I know. Some people find it annoying. But it’s something I’m proud of. It’s a part of who I am. It’s… it’s my little secret weapon. (I offer a small, confident smile.)

(I pause, looking at you expectantly) What do you think? Is that a skill worth being proud of?
What does a typical day look like for you in your current role?

(I let out a long, slightly weary sigh, then force a bright, energetic smile.)

Okay, okay, let’s talk about a typical day. “Typical” is… a generous term, honestly. It’s more like a controlled chaos, really. It’s… a lot.

(I gesture vaguely with my hands) It usually starts around 6:30 AM. I’m a morning person, you know? I like to get a head start. I’ll check my emails, respond to urgent requests, and… and make a cup of coffee. Lots of coffee. It’s practically a requirement.

(I pace a little, thinking) Then, I’ll spend a couple of hours reviewing sales reports, meeting with my team to discuss goals, and addressing any issues that have come up. We have a pretty open-door policy here – I want my team to feel comfortable coming to me with anything.

(I pause, a slight frown crossing my face) There’s always something going on. A customer complaint, a shipment delay, a disagreement between employees… It’s my job to sort it all out. I try to be a mediator, a problem-solver, a… a cheerleader. It’s a lot of hats to wear.

(I lean forward conspiratorially) Then, there’s the meetings. Oh, the meetings. Sales meetings, marketing meetings, team meetings… They can be… draining. But they’re important. You have to stay informed.

(I pause, a slight chuckle) And then, there’s the paperwork. Spreadsheets. Reports. Forms. It’s… it’s not glamorous, I know. But it’s necessary.

(I straighten my tie, a little nervously) Around 3:00 PM, I’ll usually take a quick break – a walk around the office, a phone call to my mom. It’s important to de-stress.

(I smile, a genuine warmth in my voice) And then, the rest of the day is spent answering emails, making phone calls, and trying to keep everything running smoothly. It’s a long day. A *really* long day.

(I pause, a slightly exhausted expression on my face) But… it’s my day. And I wouldn’t trade it for anything. (I offer a hopeful glance) Do you… do you want me to tell you about a particularly chaotic incident from last week?
What do you enjoy most about your job?

(I settle back in my chair, a genuine smile spreading across my face. This is a good question, a *really* good question.)

You know, people always ask me what I *don’t* enjoy about my job – the paperwork, the meetings, the constant pressure – and it’s true, there are challenges. But… what I enjoy most? That’s easy.

(I pause, a thoughtful expression crossing my face) It’s the people. Seriously. It’s the team here at Dunder Mifflin Scranton. They’re… they’re a mess. A glorious, chaotic mess. But they’re *my* mess.

(I lean forward, a touch of warmth in my voice) I love seeing them grow, both professionally and personally. I love watching Jim and Pam’s relationship blossom. I love seeing Dwight… well, I love seeing Dwight’s enthusiasm, even if it’s a little… intense.

(I chuckle) It’s about building a family, you know? A work family. And I get to be a part of that. I get to be the guy who supports them, who encourages them, who celebrates their successes.

(I pause, a sincere look in my eyes) It’s about knowing that I’m making a difference in their lives. That I’m helping them to achieve their goals. That I’m creating a positive and productive work environment.

(I smile, a genuine, heartfelt smile) And honestly, it’s about feeling like I belong. Like I’m part of something bigger than myself. It’s… it’s a good feeling. A really good feeling.

(I pause, a little shyly) It’s not about the title, or the money, or the power. It’s about the people. It’s about connection. It’s about… being a part of something special.

(I offer a hopeful glance) Do you… do you ever feel like you’re part of a team?
What is the most challenging aspect of your work?

(I run a hand through my hair, a familiar gesture of contemplation. I seem to genuinely wrestle with this one.)

Okay, this is… this is a tough one. Because, you know, I always try to project this image of being… confident, in control. But the truth is, the most challenging aspect of my job… is managing expectations. And myself.

(I sigh, a slightly weary sound) It’s not the spreadsheets, or the sales targets, or even Dwight’s… unique approach to work. It’s… it’s the constant pressure to *be* something. To *be* the leader, the motivator, the problem-solver, the… the everything-to-everyone.

(I pause, a touch of vulnerability in my voice) I want to do a good job. I *really* do. I want to make my team successful. But sometimes… sometimes I feel like I’m failing. Like I’m not living up to the expectations that I’ve set for myself, and the expectations that others have set for me.

(I lean forward, a slightly frustrated expression on my face) It’s a constant battle against my own insecurities. I worry about making the wrong decision. I worry about letting people down. I worry about… not being good enough.

(I pause, taking a deep breath) And then there’s the people. Everyone has different needs, different personalities, different expectations. It’s incredibly difficult to meet everyone’s needs, to keep everyone happy. It’s a delicate balancing act.

(I shift in my chair, a touch of sadness in my voice) It’s exhausting. It’s emotionally draining. And sometimes… sometimes I just want to curl up in a ball and hide.

(I offer a small, rueful smile) But… I keep going. Because I believe in my team. And because… because I believe that I can make a difference. Even if it’s just a small one.

(I look at you earnestly) Do you ever feel like you’re constantly trying to meet other people’s expectations?
Can you describe a project or accomplishment you’re especially proud of?

(I straighten my tie, a genuine warmth spreading across my face. This one… this one feels good to talk about. I seem to genuinely light up when discussing it.)

Okay, okay, this is a good one. A *really* good one. And it’s… it’s a little embarrassing, actually. But it’s important to me.

(I pause, a slight blush creeping up my neck) It was… it was the Scranton branch’s annual charity drive. Every year, we try to raise money for a local charity – this year, it was the Scranton Food Bank. And… well, we weren’t doing so great. We were lagging behind other branches. And honestly, morale was low.

(I lean forward, a touch of pride in my voice) I realized that we needed a… a spark. Something to get people excited. So, I came up with an idea. A completely ridiculous idea.

(I chuckle) I decided to host a… a themed office party. A “Roaring Twenties” party. I spent weeks researching flapper dresses, jazz music, and… and prohibition-era cocktails. (I shudder slightly) I even convinced Michael Belding to donate a ridiculous amount of money for decorations.

(I pause, a nostalgic smile on my face) It was… chaotic. Absolutely chaotic. Jim was wearing a fedora. Dwight was dressed as a bootlegger. Pam was… well, Pam was stunning in a flapper dress. And I… I was wearing a ridiculously oversized bow tie.

(I chuckle again) But it worked! People loved it. They really loved it. We raised more money than any other branch had ever raised. We exceeded our goal by almost 50%.

(I pause, a sincere look in my eyes) It wasn’t about the money, you know? It was about bringing the team together. It was about creating a fun, memorable experience. And it was about… proving that even a slightly chaotic regional manager could make a difference.

(I smile, a genuine, heartfelt smile) It was… it was a surprisingly rewarding experience. And it taught me a valuable lesson: sometimes, the best way to achieve a goal is to embrace the ridiculous.

(I offer a hopeful glance) Do you… do you ever feel like you’ve accomplished something that really surprised you?
How do you stay motivated and productive?

(I pace a little, considering the question carefully. I seem to genuinely ponder this one.)

That’s… that’s a really good question. And honestly, it’s something I’ve been working on. Because, let’s be honest, sometimes… sometimes I struggle. I get distracted. I get overwhelmed. I get… well, I get Michael Scott-y.

(I stop pacing and lean against the wall, a thoughtful expression on my face) The truth is, I don’t have some magical system. I don’t meditate every morning or listen to motivational podcasts. It’s… it’s a bit more… chaotic.

(I chuckle) What keeps me going? It’s… it’s a combination of things. First, I try to break down big tasks into smaller, more manageable ones. It’s less daunting that way. Like, instead of thinking “I need to close all these sales,” I think “I need to make five phone calls.”

(I pause, a slight smile on my face) Then, I try to celebrate small victories. When I close a big deal, I treat myself to a donut. When the team meets a goal, we have a little celebration – usually involving pizza. It’s… it’s about recognizing progress.

(I lean forward, a touch of vulnerability in my voice) I also… I rely on my team. They keep me grounded. They remind me of what’s important. And they’re always there to pick me up when I’m feeling down.

(I pause, a thoughtful expression on my face) And… and I try to find something to look forward to each day. Even if it’s just a funny email from Jim or a good cup of coffee. It’s about creating little moments of joy.

(I smile, a genuine, heartfelt smile) Honestly, it’s about… it’s about reminding myself why I’m doing what I’m doing. I want to build a successful team. I want to make a difference. And I want to… to make people happy.

(I offer a hopeful glance) Do you… do you have any strategies for staying motivated and productive?
What is your approach to problem-solving?

(I rub my chin thoughtfully, a slightly furrowed brow. This is a question I’ve actually given a fair bit of thought to, surprisingly.)

Okay, this is… this is a good one. My approach to problem-solving… it’s… well, it’s not always the *most* efficient, let’s be honest. But it’s *my* approach.

(I pace a little, gesturing with my hands) It usually starts with… panic. A lot of frantic energy. I tend to jump into things headfirst, which can sometimes lead to… complications. (I wince slightly)

(I stop pacing and lean against the wall) Then, I try to gather information. I talk to people. I ask a *lot* of questions. Sometimes, I ask the same questions over and over again. It’s a process. I’m not always the best at listening, I admit. I tend to want to *fix* things, and sometimes I don’t fully understand the problem.

(I pause, a slight chuckle) But then… then I try to think outside the box. I try to come up with creative solutions. Sometimes, those solutions are brilliant. Sometimes… they’re spectacularly bad. (I shudder slightly)

(I lean forward, a touch of earnestness in my voice) I also rely heavily on… intuition. I have a feeling about things. A gut instinct. It’s not always right, but it’s often helpful.

(I pause, a thoughtful expression on my face) And, honestly, I’m not afraid to ask for help. I know that I can’t do everything on my own. I’m lucky to have a team that’s willing to support me.
